intro: Quercus obtusifolia var. breviloba, commonly known as the narrow-leaf chestnut oak, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its small, oblong leaves that are typically 2–4 inches long and have a smooth, glossy upper surface. The tree produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in mixed hardwood forests. Its botanical features make it a valuable component of ecological systems in its native range.
